assumption: Static role assignment in AI-human collaboration limits effectiveness
hypothesis: Dynamic role allocation systems that adaptively assign leadership, execution, and review responsibilities between AI agents and humans based on real-time competency assessment and task requirements will produce superior research outcomes (measured by time-to-insight, solution quality, and user satisfaction) compared to static role assignments by 15-25%.
impact: Fundamental shift in collaborative AI system design

hypothesis: Research collaborations with structured iterative feedback mechanisms (hypothesis → experiment → analysis → refinement cycles) will demonstrate 20-30% higher research velocity and solution quality compared to sequential workflows, measured by publication timeline, citation impact, and peer review scores.
